pli-tv-kd6:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhūnaṃ sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhānaṃ yāgupi pītā uggacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ uggacchati.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.2.eng: At that time the monks were afflicted with autumn illness, and they could keep down neither congee nor other food.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.3.pli: Te tena kisā honti, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.3.eng: As a result, they became thin, haggard, and pale, with veins protruding all over their body.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te bhikkhū kise lūkhe dubbaṇṇe uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāte dhamanisanthatagatte, disvāna āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.4.eng: The Buddha noticed this and asked Venerable Ānanda

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.5.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, ānanda, etarahi bhikkhū kisā, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.5.eng: why they were looking so sickly.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.6.pli: “Etarahi, bhante, bhikkhūnaṃ sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhānaṃ yāgupi pītā uggacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ uggacchati.

pli-tv-kd6:1.1.7.pli: Te tena kisā honti, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā”ti.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.1.eng: Then, while reflecting in private, the Buddha thought,

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.2.pli: “etarahi kho bhikkhūnaṃ sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhānaṃ yāgupi pītā uggacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ uggacchati.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.3.pli: Te tena kisā honti, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.4.pli: Kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhesajjaṃ anujāneyyaṃ, yaṃ bhesajjañceva assa bhesajjasammatañca lokassa, āhāratthañca phareyya, na ca oḷāriko āhāro paññāyeyyā”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.4.eng: “What tonics might I allow the monks that are generally regarded as tonics, would serve as nourishment, but aren’t considered substantial food?”

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.6.comm: For an explanation of rendering bhesajja as “tonics”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.7.eng: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.7.comm: I. B. Horner translates phāṇita as “molasses”, which doesn’t quite hit the mark. SED defines phāṇita as “the inspissated juice of the sugarcane or other plants”, in other words, “cane syrup”. According to the commentary at Sp 1.623 it can be either cooked or uncooked, the difference presumably being whether the juice is raw or concentrated. “Syrup” seems closer to the mark than “molasses”.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.8.pli: bhesajjāni ceva bhesajjasammatāni ca lokassa, āhāratthañca pharanti, na ca oḷāriko āhāro paññāyati.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.8.eng: that are generally regarded as tonics, serve as nourishment, but aren’t considered substantial food.

pli-tv-kd6:1.2.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imāni pañca bhesajjāni anujāneyyaṃ, kāle paṭiggahetvā kāle paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.9.eng: Why don’t I allow them these five tonics, to be received and consumed before midday?”

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.1.eng: In the evening, when the Buddha had come out from seclusion, he gave a teaching and then told the monks what he had thought, adding:

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.2.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.3.pli: ‘etarahi kho bhikkhūnaṃ sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhānaṃ yāgupi pītā uggacchati, bhattampi bhuttaṃ uggacchati.

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.4.pli: Te tena kisā honti, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā.

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.5.pli: Kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhesajjaṃ anujāneyyaṃ, yaṃ bhesajjañceva assa bhesajjasammatañca lokassa, āhāratthañca phareyya, na ca oḷāriko āhāro paññāyeyyā’ti.

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.9.pli: bhesajjāni ceva bhesajjasammatāni ca lokassa, āhāratthañca pharanti, na ca oḷāriko āhāro paññāyati.

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.10.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imāni pañca bhesajjāni anujāneyyaṃ, kāle paṭiggahetvā kāle paribhuñjitun’ti.

pli-tv-kd6:1.3.11.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, tāni pañca bhesajjāni kāle paṭiggahetvā kāle paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.11.eng: “I allow these five tonics, to be received and consumed before midday.”

pli-tv-kd6:1.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū tāni pañca bhesajjāni kāle paṭiggahetvā kāle paribhuñjanti.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.1.eng: The monks then received and consumed the five tonics before midday.

pli-tv-kd6:1.4.2.pli: Tesaṃ yānipi tāni pākatikāni lūkhāni bhojanāni tānipi nacchādenti, pageva senesitāni.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.2.eng: But even ordinary food did not agree with them, let alone greasy food.

pli-tv-kd6:1.4.3.pli: Te tena ceva sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhā, iminā ca bhattācchādakena, tadubhayena bhiyyoso mattāya kisā honti, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.3.eng: As result of both the autumn illness and the food not agreeing with them, they became even more thin, haggard, and pale.

pli-tv-kd6:1.4.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te bhikkhū bhiyyoso mattāya kise lūkhe dubbaṇṇe uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāte dhamanisanthatagatte, disvāna āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.4.eng: Once again the Buddha noticed this and asked Venerable Ānanda

pli-tv-kd6:1.4.5.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, ānanda, etarahi bhikkhū bhiyyoso mattāya kisā, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.5.eng: why they were looking even worse.

pli-tv-kd6:1.5.1.pli: “Etarahi, bhante, bhikkhū tāni ca pañca bhesajjāni kāle paṭiggahetvā kāle paribhuñjanti.

pli-tv-kd6:1.5.2.pli: Tesaṃ yānipi tāni pākatikāni lūkhāni bhojanāni tānipi nacchādenti, pageva senesitāni.

pli-tv-kd6:1.5.3.pli: Te tena ceva sāradikena ābādhena phuṭṭhā, iminā ca bhattācchādakena, tadubhayena bhiyyoso mattāya kisā, lūkhā, dubbaṇṇā, uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā, dhamanisanthatagattā”ti.

pli-tv-kd6:1.5.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:1.5.4.eng: The Buddha then gave a teaching, and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:1.5.5.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, tāni pañca bhesajjāni paṭiggahetvā kālepi vikālepi paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:1.5.5.eng: “I allow the five tonics to be received and consumed both before and after midday.”

pli-tv-kd6:2.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vasehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:2.1.1.eng: At that time the sick monks needed fat as a tonic.

pli-tv-kd6:2.1.4.eng: bear fat, fish fat, alligator fat, pig fat, and donkey fat.

pli-tv-kd6:2.1.5.pli: kāle paṭiggahitaṃ kāle nippakkaṃ kāle saṃsaṭṭhaṃ telaparibhogena paribhuñjituṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:2.1.5.eng: They should be received, melted, and mixed with oil before midday, and then used.

pli-tv-kd6:2.2.1.pli: Vikāle ce, bhikkhave, paṭiggahitaṃ vikāle nippakkaṃ vikāle saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti tiṇṇaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:2.2.1.eng: If you receive, melt, and mix them with oil after midday, and then use them, you commit three offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:2.2.2.pli: Kāle ce, bhikkhave, paṭiggahitaṃ vikāle nippakkaṃ vikāle saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dvinnaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:2.2.2.eng: If you receive them before midday, but melt and mix them with oil after midday, and then use them, you commit two offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:2.2.3.pli: Kāle ce, bhikkhave, paṭiggahitaṃ kāle nippakkaṃ vikāle saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-kd6:2.2.3.eng: If you receive and melt them before midday, but mix them with oil after midday, and then use them, you commit one offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:2.2.4.pli: Kāle ce, bhikkhave, paṭiggahitaṃ kāle nippakkaṃ kāle saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, anāpattī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:2.2.4.eng: If you receive, melt, and mix them with oil before midday, and then use them, there is no offense.”

pli-tv-kd6:3.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ mūlehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:3.1.1.eng: At that time the sick monks needed medicinal roots.

pli-tv-kd6:3.1.4.pli: haliddiṃ, siṅgiveraṃ, vacaṃ, vacattaṃ, ativisaṃ, kaṭukarohiṇiṃ, usīraṃ, bhaddamuttakaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi mūlāni bhesajjāni, neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti, na bhojanīye bhojanīyatthaṃ pharanti, tāni—
pli-tv-kd6:3.1.4.eng: turmeric, ginger, sweet flag, white sweet flag, atis root, black hellebore, vetiver root, nut grass, and whatever other medicinal roots there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.
pli-tv-kd6:3.1.4.comm: For a discussion of these names and those below, see Appendix of Plants.

pli-tv-kd6:3.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life

pli-tv-kd6:3.1.6.eng: and use them when there’s a reason.

pli-tv-kd6:3.1.7.eng: If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:3.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ mūlehi bhesajjehi piṭṭhehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:3.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the sick monks needed medicinal root flour.

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ kasāvehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:4.1.1.eng: The sick monks needed bitter medicines.

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.3.eng: “I allow bitter medicines from these plants:

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.4.pli: nimbakasāvaṃ, kuṭajakasāvaṃ, paṭolakasāvaṃ, phaggavakasāvaṃ, nattamālakasāvaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi kasāvāni bhesajjāni neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti, na bhojanīye bhojanīyatthaṃ pharanti, tāni—
pli-tv-kd6:4.1.4.eng: neem tree, arctic snow, pointed gourd, white fig, Indian beech, and whatever other bitter medicines there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.6.eng: and use them when there’s a reason.

pli-tv-kd6:4.1.7.eng: If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:5.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṇṇehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:5.1.1.eng: The sick monks needed medicinal leaves.

pli-tv-kd6:5.1.3.eng: “I allow medicinal leaves from these plants:

pli-tv-kd6:5.1.4.pli: nimbapaṇṇaṃ, kuṭajapaṇṇaṃ, paṭolapaṇṇaṃ, sulasipaṇṇaṃ, kappāsapaṇṇaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi paṇṇāni bhesajjāni, neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti, na bhojanīye bhojanīyatthaṃ pharanti …
pli-tv-kd6:5.1.4.eng: neem tree, arctic snow, pointed gourd, holy basil, cotton plant, and whatever other leaf medicines there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.

pli-tv-kd6:5.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life and use them when there’s a reason. If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:6.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ phalehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:6.1.1.eng: The sick monks needed medicinal fruits.

pli-tv-kd6:6.1.3.eng: “I allow medicinal fruits from these plants:

pli-tv-kd6:6.1.4.pli: bilaṅgaṃ, pippaliṃ, maricaṃ, harītakaṃ, vibhītakaṃ, āmalakaṃ, goṭṭhaphalaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi phalāni bhesajjāni, neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti, na bhojanīye bhojanīyatthaṃ pharanti …
pli-tv-kd6:6.1.4.eng: false black pepper, long pepper, black pepper, chebulic myrobalan, belleric myrobalan, emblic myrobalan, crepe ginger, and whatever other medicinal fruits there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.

pli-tv-kd6:6.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life and use them when there’s a reason. If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:7.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ jatūhi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:7.1.1.eng: The sick monks needed medicinal gum.

pli-tv-kd6:7.1.4.pli: hiṅguṃ, hiṅgujatuṃ, hiṅgusipāṭikaṃ, takaṃ, takapattiṃ, takapaṇṇiṃ, sajjulasaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi jatūni bhesajjāni, neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti …
pli-tv-kd6:7.1.4.eng: gum exuded from the asafoetida shrub, gum from the twigs and leaves of the asafoetida shrub, gum from the leaves of the asafoetida shrub, taka gum, taka-leaf gum, gum from heated taka foliage, resin, and whatever other medicinal gums there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.

pli-tv-kd6:7.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life and use them when there’s a reason. If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:8.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ loṇehi bhesajjehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:8.1.1.eng: The sick monks needed medicinal salts.

pli-tv-kd6:8.1.4.pli: sāmuddaṃ, kāḷaloṇaṃ, sindhavaṃ, ubbhidaṃ, bilaṃ, yāni vā panaññānipi atthi loṇāni bhesajjāni, neva khādanīye khādanīyatthaṃ pharanti, na bhojanīye bhojanīyatthaṃ pharanti, tāni—
pli-tv-kd6:8.1.4.eng: sea salt, black salt, hill salt, soil salt, red salt, and whatever other medicinal salts there are that don’t serve as fresh or cooked food.
pli-tv-kd6:8.1.4.comm: Sp 3.263: Sindhavanti setavaṇṇaṁ pabbate uṭṭhahati, “Sindhava: it appears as a white color in the hills.” Sp 3.263: Ubbhidanti bhūmito aṅkuraṁ uṭṭhahati, “Ubbhida: it appears like a sprout from the earth.” But Sp-ṭ 3.263 says: Ubbhidaṁ nāma ūsarapaṁsumayaṁ, “What is made from saline soil is called ubbhidaṁ.” Sp 3.263: Bilanti dabbasambhārehi saddhiṁ pacitaṁ, taṁ rattavaṇṇaṁ, “Bila: it is boiled together with a material that has the color red.”

pli-tv-kd6:8.1.5.eng: After receiving them, you may keep them for life

pli-tv-kd6:8.1.6.eng: and use them when there’s a reason.

pli-tv-kd6:8.1.7.eng: If you use them when there’s no reason, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd6:9.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato ānandassa upajjhāyassa āyasmato belaṭṭhasīsassa thullakacchābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:9.1.1.eng: At this time Venerable Ānanda’s preceptor, Venerable Belaṭṭhasīsa, had carbuncles,

pli-tv-kd6:9.1.2.pli: Tassa lasikāya cīvarāni kāye lagganti, tāni bhikkhū udakena temetvā temetvā apakaḍḍhanti.
pli-tv-kd6:9.1.2.eng: the pus making his robes adhere to his body. The monks kept on wetting his robes to remove the pus.

pli-tv-kd6:9.1.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā senāsanacārikaṃ āhiṇḍanto te bhikkhū tāni cīvarāni udakena temetvā temetvā apakaḍḍhante, disvāna yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:9.1.3.eng: As the Buddha was walking about the dwellings, he noticed this. He went up to them and said,

pli-tv-kd6:9.1.5.pli: “Imassa, bhante, āyasmato thullakacchābādho, lasikāya cīvarāni kāye lagganti, tāni mayaṃ udakena temetvā temetvā apakaḍḍhāmā”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:9.1.5.eng: “He has carbuncles, sir. That’s why we’re doing this.”

pli-tv-kd6:9.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:9.2.2.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yassa kaṇḍu vā, piḷakā vā, assāvo vā, thullakacchu vā ābādho, kāyo vā duggandho, cuṇṇāni bhesajjāni;
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.2.eng: “For anyone who has an itch, a boil, a running sore, a carbuncle, or whose body smells, I allow medicinal powders.
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.2.comm: Sp 2.539: Piḷakāti lohitatuṇḍikā sukhumapiḷakā, “Piḷaka is a minor piḷaka with blood on the tip.” Sp 2.539: Thullakacchu vā ābādhoti mahāpiḷakābādho vuccati, “Thullakacchu vā ābādha is a sickness with large boils.”

pli-tv-kd6:9.2.3.eng: If you’re not sick, I allow detergent, soap, and cleaning agents.
pli-tv-kd6:9.2.3.comm: For an explanation of rendering chakaṇa and mattika as respectively “detergent” and “soap”, see Appendix of Technical Terms. For an explanation of rendering rajananippakka as “cleaning agents”, see Appendix of Medical Terminology.

pli-tv-kd6:9.2.4.eng: And I allow a mortar and pestle.”

pli-tv-kd6:10.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ cuṇṇehi bhesajjehi cālitehi attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:10.1.1.eng: Soon afterwards the sick monks needed sifted medicinal powders.

pli-tv-kd6:10.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno amanussikābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:10.2.1.eng: On one occasion a monk was possessed by a spirit.

pli-tv-kd6:10.2.2.pli: Taṃ ācariyupajjhāyā upaṭṭhahantā nāsakkhiṃsu arogaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:10.2.2.eng: His teacher and preceptor who were nursing him were not able to cure him.

pli-tv-kd6:10.2.3.pli: So sūkarasūnaṃ gantvā āmakamaṃsaṃ khādi, āmakalohitaṃ pivi.
pli-tv-kd6:10.2.3.eng: He then went to a pigs’ slaughterhouse to eat raw meat and drink blood.

pli-tv-kd6:10.2.4.eng: As a result, he became well.

pli-tv-kd6:10.2.6.eng: “For one who is possessed, I allow raw meat and raw blood.”

pli-tv-kd6:11.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno cakkhurogābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:11.1.1.eng: At that time a monk was afflicted with an eye-disease.

pli-tv-kd6:11.1.2.pli: Taṃ bhikkhū pariggahetvā uccārampi passāvampi nikkhāmenti.
pli-tv-kd6:11.1.2.eng: The monks had to hold him while he urinated and defecated.

pli-tv-kd6:11.1.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā senāsanacārikaṃ āhiṇḍanto te bhikkhū taṃ bhikkhuṃ pariggahetvā uccārampi passāvampi nikkhāmente, disvāna yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:11.1.3.eng: Just then, as the Buddha was walking about the dwellings, he noticed this. He then went up to them and said,

pli-tv-kd6:11.2.2.pli: Imaṃ mayaṃ pariggahetvā uccārampi passāvampi nikkhāmemā”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.2.eng: That’s why we do this for him.”

pli-tv-kd6:11.2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.3.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:11.2.5.eng: black ointment, mixed ointment, river ointment, red ocher, and soot.”
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.5.comm: Sp 3.365: Rasañjanaṁ nānāsambhārehi kataṁ, “Rasañjana is made with many ingredients.” Sp 3.365: Sotañjananti nadīsotādīsu uppajjanakaṁ añjanaṁ, “Sotañjana: an ointment being produced in the stream of rivers.”

pli-tv-kd6:11.2.8.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, candanaṃ, tagaraṃ, kāḷānusāriyaṃ, tālīsaṃ, bhaddamuttakan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.8.eng: “I allow sandal, crape jasmine, Indian valerian, coffee plum, and nut grass.”
pli-tv-kd6:11.2.8.comm: For a discussion of these, see Appendix of Plants.

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū piṭṭhāni añjanāni carukesupi sarāvakesupi nikkhipanti;
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.1.eng: At that time the monks put their ointments in pots and scoops.

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.2.eng: The ointment was contaminated with grass, dust, and dirt.

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacā añjaniyo dhārenti—
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.5.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six used luxurious ointment boxes
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.5.comm: I here render uccāvaca as luxurious. This rendering seems required by the context. See also use of this word at SN 2.29:7.1.

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.8.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.11.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:12.1.12.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, aṭṭhimayaṃ, dantamayaṃ, visāṇamayaṃ, naḷamayaṃ, veḷumayaṃ, kaṭṭhamayaṃ, jatumayaṃ, phalamayaṃ, lohamayaṃ, saṅkhanābhimayan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.12.eng: I allow ointment boxes made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, and shell.”
pli-tv-kd6:12.1.12.comm: Khuddasikkhā-purāṇaṭīkā 185: Āmalakakakkādīhi katā phalamayā, “Made of fruit means made from ground emblic myrobalan, etc.”

pli-tv-kd6:12.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena añjaniyo apārutā honti, tiṇacuṇṇehipi paṃsukehipi okiriyanti.
pli-tv-kd6:12.2.1.eng: At that time the ointment boxes were not covered. The ointment was contaminated with grass, dust, and dirt.

pli-tv-kd6:12.2.6.eng: “I allow you to tie it onto the ointment box with a string.”

pli-tv-kd6:12.2.9.eng: “I allow you to sew it together with thread.”

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū aṅguliyā añjanti, akkhīni dukkhāni honti.
pli-tv-kd6:12.3.1.eng: At that time the monks put the ointment on with their fingers. As a result their eyes hurt.

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.3.comm: Appendix of Medical Terminology for a list of allowable medical equipment.

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacā añjanisalākāyo dhārenti—
pli-tv-kd6:12.3.4.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six used luxurious ointment sticks

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.7.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:12.3.11.eng: I allow ointment sticks made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, and shell.”

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena añjanisalākā bhūmiyaṃ patitā pharusā hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:12.4.1.eng: The monks dropped the ointment sticks on the ground. The sticks became rough.

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.3.eng: “I allow a case for the ointment stick.”
pli-tv-kd6:12.4.3.comm: Reading salākodhāniya with the PTS edition.

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū añjanimpi añjanisalākampi hatthena pariharanti.
pli-tv-kd6:12.4.4.eng: The monks carried the ointment boxes and sticks in their hands.

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.6.eng: “I allow a bag for the ointment box.”

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.7.eng: They did not have a shoulder strap.

pli-tv-kd6:12.4.9.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for tying it.”
pli-tv-kd6:12.4.9.comm: Vin-ālaṅ-ṭ 34.67: Añjanitthavikāya aṁse lagganatthāya aṁsabaddhakampi bandhanasuttakampi vaṭṭati, “A shoulder strap and also a bandhanasuttaka is allowed for the purpose of the hanging of the ointment-box bag from the shoulder.”

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa sīsābhitāpo hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:13.1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha had a headache.

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.7.eng: The oil dripped from the nose.

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacā natthukaraṇiyo dhārenti—
pli-tv-kd6:13.1.10.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six used luxurious nose droppers

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.13.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.16.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:13.1.17.eng: I allow nose droppers made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal,

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.7.pli: Taññeva vaṭṭiṃ ālimpetvā pivanti, kaṇṭho dahati.
pli-tv-kd6:13.2.7.eng: They just lit the wick and inhaled the smoke. They burned their throat.

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacāni dhūmanettāni dhārenti—
pli-tv-kd6:13.2.10.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six used luxurious tubes

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.13.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.16.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.17.eng: I allow tubes made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, and shell.”

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.18.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dhūmanettāni apārutāni honti, pāṇakā pavisanti.
pli-tv-kd6:13.2.18.eng: At that time the tubes were not covered. Insects crawled inside of them.

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.21.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dhūmanettāni hatthena pariharanti.
pli-tv-kd6:13.2.21.eng: At that time the monks carried the tubes in their hands.

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.23.eng: “I allow a bag for the tubes.”

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.26.eng: “I allow a bag with two compartments.”

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.27.eng: They did not have a shoulder strap.

pli-tv-kd6:13.2.29.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for fastening it.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa vātābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha had a certain disease.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.1.comm: Vātābādha, literally, “a wind disease”. According to the Indian system of classification, this included a number of illnesses, such as arthritis. Since intestinal gas is elsewhere called udaravātābādha, “stomach wind disease”, it is unclear what is meant in this context. The commentaries are silent.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.3.eng: he needed a heated concoction of oil.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.5.eng: “I allow a heated concoction of oil.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.5.comm: Sp 3.267: Anujānāmi bhikkhave telapākanti yaṅkiñci bhesajjapakkhittaṁ sabbaṁ anuññātameva hoti, “I allow telapāka: whatever medicines are included are all allowed.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.6.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana telapāke majjaṃ pakkhipitabbaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.6.eng: They wanted to add alcohol to that concoction.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.8.eng: “I allow alcohol in a heated concoction of oil.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū atipakkhittamajjāni telāni pacanti, tāni pivitvā majjanti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.9.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six heated oil with too much alcohol. They drank it and became drunk.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.11.eng: “You shouldn’t drink heated oil with too much alcohol.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.12.eng: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.

pli-tv-kd6:14.1.13.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ telapāke majjassa na vaṇṇo na gandho na raso paññāyati, evarūpaṃ majjapakkhittaṃ telaṃ pātun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.1.13.eng: I allow you to drink heated oil if there is no discernible color, smell, or taste of alcohol.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhūnaṃ bahuṃ atipakkhittamajjaṃ telaṃ pakkaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.2.1.eng: The monks had heated much oil with too much alcohol.

pli-tv-kd6:14.2.2.pli: Atha kho bhikkhūnaṃ etadahosi—“kathaṃ nu kho atipakkhittamajje tele paṭipajjitabban”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:14.2.2.eng: They did not know what to do with it.

pli-tv-kd6:14.2.4.eng: “I allow you to determine it for external use.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.2.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa bahutaraṃ telaṃ pakkaṃ hoti, telabhājanaṃ na vijjati.
pli-tv-kd6:14.2.5.eng: Pilindavaccha had more heated oil, but there was no vessel for storing it.

pli-tv-kd6:14.2.8.eng: made of metal, made of wood, made of fruit.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.2.8.comm: Vmv 3.305: Phalatumbo nāma lābuādi, “A vessel made of fruit is a gourd, etc.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa aṅgavāto hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.1.eng: At that time Pilindavaccha had arthritis of the hands and feet.
pli-tv-kd6:14.3.1.comm: “Arthiritis of the hands and feet” renders aṅgavāta, literally “wind of the limbs”. I follow the commentarial explanation at Sp 3.267: Aṅgavātoti hatthapāde vāto, “Aṅgavāta means wind in the hands and the feet.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.6.comm: Sp 3.267: Sambhārasedanti nānāvidhapaṇṇabhaṅgasedaṁ, “Sambhārasedanti: sweating with various shredded leaves.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.7.eng: He still did not get better.

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.10.eng: He still did not get better.

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.12.comm: Sp 3.267: Bhaṅgodakanti nānāpaṇṇabhaṅgakuthitaṁ udakaṁ; tehi paṇṇehi ca udakena ca siñcitvā siñcitvā sedetabbo, “Bhaṅgodaka: water with various putrid, shredded leaves. One is made to sweat by repeated pouring the water and the leaves.” The commentary brings in the idea of sweating, saying that the hemp water was for external use, yet neither is mentioned in the Canonical text. In fact, although the use of bhaṅgodaka in the Canonical text is immediately preceded by the three separate treatments that involve sweating (Kd 6:14.3.3–14.3.9), it is not mentioned in connection with bhaṅgodaka. Moreover, the commentary interprets bhaṅga to mean shredded (leaves), with the idea of leaves merely implied. The more straightforward interpretation is that bhaṅga refers to hemp, which is how I. B. Horner understands it. It seems possible, then, that this refers to hemp water, or cannabis water, that was taken as an internal medicine. Given that cannabis is known to alleviate arthritis symptoms, this is perhaps not as surprising as it may seem.

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.13.eng: He still did not get better.

pli-tv-kd6:14.3.15.comm: Sp 3.267: Udakakoṭṭhakanti udakakoṭṭhe cāṭiṁ vā doṇiṁ vā uṇhodakassa pūretvā tattha pavisitvā sedakammakaraṇaṁ anujānāmīti attho, “Udakakoṭṭhaka: the meaning is ‘I allow the causing of sweating by entering a tank or trough filled with hot water in a bathroom.’”

pli-tv-kd6:14.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa pabbavāto hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.4.1.comm: “Arthiritis” renders pabbavāta Sp 3.267: Pabbavāto hotīti pabbe pabbe vāto vijjhati, “Pabbavāta means wind piercing in the various joints.” Although the exact meaning of vāta is not specified, it typically refers to arthritis. See SED. Here it presumably refers to joints other than the hands and feet, which are mentioned above.

pli-tv-kd6:14.4.6.eng: “I allow bloodletting and receiving it in a horn.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.4.6.comm: I have not been able to trace any explanation of this seemingly strange practice, either in the commentaries or elsewhere.

pli-tv-kd6:14.4.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato pilindavacchassa pādā phalitā honti.

pli-tv-kd6:14.4.12.eng: “I allow you to make foot salve.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.4.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno gaṇḍābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.4.13.eng: At that time a monk was afflicted with abscesses.
pli-tv-kd6:14.4.13.comm: “Abscess” renders gaṇḍa. For a discussion of this word, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd6:14.5.3.comm: Sp 3.267: Kabaḷikanti vaṇamukhe sattupiṇḍaṁ pakkhipituṁ, “Kabaḷika means to place a lump of flour on the sore.” Vmv 3.267: Kabaḷikāti upanāhabhesajjaṁ, “Kabaḷika: a lasting medicine.” The definition in DOP is not quite right.

pli-tv-kd6:14.5.9.eng: “I allow you to sprinkle it with mustard powder.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.5.13.comm: Sp 3.267: Vaḍḍhamaṁsanti adhikamaṁsaṁ āṇi viya uṭṭhahati, “Vaḍḍhamaṁsa means an excess of flesh was sticking out like a peg.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.5.15.eng: “I allow you to cut it with a razor.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.5.15.comm: Sp 3.267: Loṇasakkharikāya chinditunti khurena chindituṁ, “Loṇasakkharikāya chindituṁ means to cut with a razor.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.5.21.eng: “I allow a bandage and all treatments for sores.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.1.eng: On one occasion a certain monk was bitten by a snake.

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.3.eng: “I allow you to give him the four foul edibles:

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.6.eng: “Do they need to be received or not?”
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.6.comm: The question seems to be whether these can be given to the bitten person in an unreceived state, appaṭiggahitāni, or whether they have to be received first, paṭiggahetabbānī.

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.8.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, sati kappiyakārake paṭiggahāpetuṃ, asati kappiyakārake sāmaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.8.eng: “They should be received if there is an attendant. If there isn’t, I allow you to take them yourself and then eat them.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.8.comm: “Should” renders anujānāmi. For a discussion of this word, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarena bhikkhunā visaṃ pītaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.9.eng: On one occasion a monk had drunk poison.

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.11.eng: “I allow you to give him feces to drink.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.13.eng: “Does it need to be received or not?”

pli-tv-kd6:14.6.15.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yaṃ karonto paṭiggaṇhāti, sveva paṭiggaho kato, na puna paṭiggahetabbo”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.6.15.eng: “I allow the one who is excreting it to receive it. When he’s received it, it doesn’t need to be received again.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno gharadinnakābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.1.eng: On one occasion a monk was sick from a drug.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.1.comm: Sp 3.269: Gharadinnakābādhoti vasīkaraṇapānakasamuṭṭhitarogo, “Gharadinnakābādha is a sickness coming from drinking an overpowering drink.” Sp-ṭ 3.269: Gharadinnakābādho nāma vasīkaraṇatthāya gharaṇiyā dinnabhesajjasamuṭṭhito ābādho, “Gharadinnakābādha is the name of a sickness coming from medicine given by a housewife for the purpose of overpowering.” The point seems to be that one is given a substance so that one can subsequently be overpowered.

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.3.eng: “I allow him to drink mud from a plow.”
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.3.comm: Sītāloḷī literally means “what is mixed in a furrow”. Sp 3.269: Sītāloḷinti naṅgalena kasantassa phāle laggamattikaṁ udakena āloḷetvā pāyetuṁ anujānāmīti attho, “Sītāloḷī: the meaning is ‘I allow you to drink a mixture of water and the clay sticking to a plowshare of one plowing with a plow.’”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu duṭṭhagahaṇiko hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.4.eng: On one occasion a certain monk had indigestion.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.4.comm: Sp 3.269: Duṭṭhagahaṇikoti vipannagahaṇiko; kicchena uccāro nikkhamatīti attho, “Duṭṭhagahaṇiko: one whose stomach has failed; the meaning is he has difficulty excreting feces.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno paṇḍurogābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.7.eng: On one occasion a certain monk suffered from jaundice.

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.9.eng: “I allow him to drink chebulic myrobalan soaked in cattle urine.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno chavidosābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.10.eng: On one occasion a certain monk suffered from a skin disease.

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.12.eng: “I allow you to make a scented ointment.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu abhisannakāyo hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.13.eng: On one occasion a monk’s body was full of impurities.
pli-tv-kd6:14.7.13.comm: Sp 3.269: Abhisannakāyoti ussannadosakāyo, “Abhisannakāya means the body is full of impurities.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.15.eng: “I allow him to drink a purgative.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.18.comm: Sp 3.269: Acchakañjiyanti taṇḍulodakamaṇḍo, “Acchakañjiya: the cream of rice water.”

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.21.comm: Sp 3.269: Akaṭayusanti asiniddho muggapacitapānīyo, “Akaṭayūsa is drinkable mung beans that have been boiled without oil.” Sp-ṭ 3.269, however, says: Akaṭayūsenāti anabhisaṅkhatena muggayūsena, “Akaṭayūsena means the juice of unprepared mung beans.” This would seem to mean the raw juice of mung beans. I follow the more ancient authority.

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.24.comm: Sp 3.269: Kaṭākaṭanti sova dhotasiniddho, “Kaṭākaṭa the same (as the previous) but washed in oil.” Sp-ṭ 3.269, however, says: Kaṭākaṭenāti mugge pacitvā acāletvāva parissāvitena muggasūpenāti, “Kaṭākaṭa means mung-bean soup made by boiling mung beans and then filtering it without stirring.” But this seems indistinguishable from the previous medicine, the mung-bean broth.

pli-tv-kd6:14.7.27.comm: Sp 3.269: Paṭicchādanīyenāti maṁsarasena, “Paṭicchādanīyena means having the juice of meat.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā pilindavaccho rājagahe pabbhāraṃ sodhāpeti leṇaṃ kattukāmo.
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha, intending to build a shelter.

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro yenāyasmā pilindavaccho tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.2.eng: Just then King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.5.eng: “I’m clearing the hillside, great king. I want to build a shelter.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.8.pli: “Tena hi, bhante, bhagavantaṃ paṭipucchitvā mama āroceyyāthā”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.8.eng: “Well then, sir, please ask the Buddha and tell me the outcome.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.9.pli: “Evaṃ, mahārājā”ti kho āyasmā pilindavaccho rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paccassosi.

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi, samādapesi, samuttejesi, sampahaṃsesi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.1.eng: Pilindavaccha instructed, inspired, and gladdened King Bimbisāra with a teaching,

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.2.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmatā pilindavacchena dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.2.eng: after which the king got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated Pilindavaccha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho bhagavato santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.3.eng: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha sent a message to the Buddha:

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.4.pli: “rājā, bhante, māgadho seniyo bimbisāro ārāmikaṃ dātukāmo.
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.4.eng: “Sir, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wishes to provide a monastery worker.

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.5.pli: Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, mayā paṭipajjitabban”ti?

pli-tv-kd6:15.2.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.6.eng: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro yenāyasmā pilindavaccho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.1.eng: Once again King Bimbisāra went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.3.eng: “Sir, has the Buddha allowed monastery workers?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.5.eng: “Well then, I’ll provide you with a monastery worker.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmato pilindavacchassa ārāmikaṃ paṭissutvā, vissaritvā, cirena satiṃ paṭilabhitvā, aññataraṃ sabbatthakaṃ mahāmattaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.6.eng: Yet after making this promise, he forgot, and only remembered after a long time. He then addressed the official in charge of practical affairs:

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.7.pli: “yo mayā, bhaṇe, ayyassa ārāmiko paṭissuto, dinno so ārāmiko”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.7.eng: “Listen, has the monastery worker I promised been provided?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.3.9.pli: “Kīva ciraṃ nu kho, bhaṇe, ito hi taṃ hotī”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.9.eng: “How long has it been since we made that promise?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.1.pli: Atha kho so mahāmatto rattiyo gaṇetvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.1.eng: The official counted the days and said,

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.3.pli: “Tena hi, bhaṇe, ayyassa pañca ārāmikasatāni dehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.3.eng: “Well then, provide him with five hundred monastery workers.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.5.pli: kho so mahāmatto rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paṭissutvā āyasmato pilindavacchassa pañca ārāmikasatāni pādāsi, pāṭiyekko gāmo nivisi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.5.eng: The official provided Pilindavaccha with those monastery workers, and a separate village was established.

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.6.eng: They called it “The Monastery Workers’ Village” and “Pilinda Village”.

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā pilindavaccho tasmiṃ gāmake kulūpako hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.7.eng: And Pilindavaccha began associating with the families in that village.

pli-tv-kd6:15.4.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya pilindagāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.8.eng: After robing up one morning, he took his bowl and robe and went to Pilinda Village for alms.

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tasmiṃ gāmake ussavo hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.1.eng: At that time they were holding a celebration in that village,

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.2.eng: and the children were dressed up in ornaments and garlands.

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho pilindagāmake sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caramāno yena aññatarassa ārāmikassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.3.eng: As Pilindavaccha was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of a certain monastery worker where he sat down on the prepared seat.

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tassā ārāmikiniyā dhītā aññe dārake alaṅkate mālākite passitvā rodati—
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.4.eng: Just then the daughter of the house had seen the other children dressed up in ornaments and garlands. She cried, saying,

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.5.eng: “I want a garland! I want ornaments!”

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho taṃ ārāmikiniṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.8.pli: “Ayaṃ, bhante, dārikā aññe dārake alaṅkate mālākite passitvā rodati—

pli-tv-kd6:15.5.10.pli: Kuto amhākaṃ duggatānaṃ mālā, kuto alaṅkāro”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.10.eng: adding, “Poor people like us can’t afford garlands and ornaments.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho aññataraṃ tiṇaṇḍupakaṃ gahetvā taṃ ārāmikiniṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.1.eng: Pilindavaccha then took a pad of grass and said to the mother,

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.2.eng: “Here, place this on the girl’s head.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.3.pli: Atha kho sā ārāmikinī taṃ tiṇaṇḍupakaṃ gahetvā tassā dārikāya sīse paṭimuñci.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.4.pli: Sā ahosi suvaṇṇamālā abhirūpā, dassanīyā, pāsādikā;
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.4.eng: and it turned into a beautiful golden garland.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.5.eng: Even the royal compound had nothing like it.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.6.pli: Manussā rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa ārocesuṃ—

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.7.pli: “amukassa, deva, ārāmikassa ghare suvaṇṇamālā abhirūpā, dassanīyā, pāsādikā;
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.7.eng: “Sir, in the house of a such-and-such a monastery worker there’s a beautiful golden garland.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.8.eng: Even in your court, sir, there’s nothing like it.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.9.eng: So how did those poor people get it?

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.11.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro taṃ ārāmikakulaṃ bandhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.11.eng: King Bimbisāra then had that family imprisoned.

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā pilindavaccho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya pilindagāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.1.eng: Once again Pilindavaccha robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and went to Pilinda Village for alms.

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.2.pli: Pilindagāmake sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caramāno yena tassa ārāmikassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paṭivissake pucchi—
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.2.eng: As he was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of that same monastery worker. He then asked the neighbors what had happened to that family.

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.4.eng: “The king had jailed them, venerable, because of that golden garland.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho yena rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.5.eng: Pilindavaccha went to King Bimbisāra’s house, where he sat down on the prepared seat.

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro yenāyasmā pilindavaccho tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ pilindavacchaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.6.eng: King Bimbisāra approached Pilindavaccha, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-kd6:15.7.7.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ āyasmā pilindavaccho etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.1.eng: “Great king, why have you jailed the family of that monastery worker?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.2.pli: “Tassa, bhante, ārāmikassa ghare suvaṇṇamālā abhirūpā, dassanīyā, pāsādikā;
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.2.eng: “Sir, in the house of that monastery worker there was a beautiful golden garland.

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.3.eng: Even the royal compound has nothing like it.

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.4.eng: So how did those poor people get it?

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pilindavaccho rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa pāsādaṃ suvaṇṇanti adhimucci;
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.6.eng: Pilindavaccha then focused his mind on turning King Bimbisāra’s stilt house into gold.

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.7.eng: As a result, the whole house became gold.

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.8.pli: “Idaṃ pana te, mahārāja, tāva bahuṃ suvaṇṇaṃ kuto”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.8.eng: He said, “Great king, how did you get so much gold?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.8.9.pli: “Aññātaṃ, bhante, ayyasseveso iddhānubhāvo”ti taṃ ārāmikakulaṃ muñcāpesi.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.9.eng: “Understood, sir! It’s your supernormal power.” And he released that family.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.2.pli: “ayyena kira pilindavacchena sarājikāya parisāya uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassitan”ti—
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.2.eng: “They say Venerable Pilindavaccha has performed a superhuman feat, a wonder of supernormal power, for the king and his court!”

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.3.pli: attamanā abhippasannā āyasmato pilindavacchassa pañca bhesajjāni abhihariṃsu, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.3.eng: Delighted, and gaining confidence in Pilindavaccha, they brought him the five tonics:

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.4.eng: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.5.pli: Pakatiyāpi ca āyasmā pilindavaccho lābhī hoti pañcannaṃ bhesajjānaṃ;
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.5.eng: Ordinarily, too, Pilindavaccha was getting the five tonics.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.6.eng: Since he was getting so much, he gave it away to his followers,

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.7.eng: who ended up with an abundance of tonics.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.8.pli: laddhaṃ laddhaṃ kolambepi, ghaṭepi, pūretvā paṭisāmeti;
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.8.eng: After filling up basins and waterpots and setting these aside,

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.9.eng: they filled their water filters and bags and hung these in the windows.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.11.eng: the dwellings became infested with rats.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.12.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.12.eng: When people walking about the dwellings noticed this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.13.pli: “antokoṭṭhāgārikā ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā, seyyathāpi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.13.eng: “These Sakyan monastics are hoarding goods indoors, just like King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha!”

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.1.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.2.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā, te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.2.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.3.eng: “How can these monks choose to live with such abundance?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.4.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū te anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.4.eng: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.5.pli: “saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, bhikkhū evarūpāya bāhullāya cetentī”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.5.eng: “Is it true, monks, that there are monks who live like this?”

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.7.pli: vigarahitvā dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.7.eng: After rebuking them, the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.8.pli: “yāni kho pana tāni gilānānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭisāyanīyāni bhesajjāni, seyyathidaṃ—sappi, navanītaṃ, telaṃ, madhu, phāṇitaṃ, tāni paṭiggahetvā sattāhaparamaṃ sannidhikārakaṃ paribhuñjitabbāni. Taṃ atikkāmayato yathādhammo kāretabbo”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:15.10.8.eng: “After being received, the tonics allowable for sick monks—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—should be used from storage for at most seven days. If you use them longer than that, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.9.eng: The first section for recitation on allowable medicines is finished.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:16.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Sāvatthī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā kaṅkhārevato antarāmagge guḷakaraṇaṃ, okkamitvā guḷe piṭṭhampi chārikampi pakkhipante, disvāna—
pli-tv-kd6:16.1.2.eng: While they were traveling, Venerable Revata the Doubter saw a sugar factory. As he approached, he noticed they were mixing the sugar with flour and ash. He thought,
pli-tv-kd6:16.1.2.comm: Sp-ṭ 3.272: Guḷakaraṇanti guḷakaraṇaṭṭhānaṁ, ucchusālanti vuttaṁ hoti, “Guḷakaraṇan: a place for making sugar. It is called a sugarcane building.”

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.3.pli: “akappiyo guḷo sāmiso, na kappati guḷo vikāle paribhuñjitun”ti—
pli-tv-kd6:16.1.3.eng: “Sugar mixed with food is unallowable, and so it’s unallowable to eat sugar at the wrong time,”

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.4.eng: and being afraid of wrongdoing, he and his followers did not take sugar.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.5.pli: Yepissa sotabbaṃ maññanti, tepi guḷaṃ na paribhuñjanti.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.7.eng: “Why are they adding flour and ash to the sugar?”

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.9.pli: “Sace, bhikkhave, thaddhatthāya guḷe piṭṭhampi chārikampi pakkhipanti, so ca guḷotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-kd6:16.1.9.eng: “If they add flour or ash to sugar to harden it, it’s still considered sugar.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.10.eng: I allow you to eat as much sugar as you like.”

pli-tv-kd6:16.2.1.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā kaṅkhārevato antarāmagge vacce muggaṃ jātaṃ, passitvā—
pli-tv-kd6:16.2.1.eng: While still traveling, Revata noticed mung beans sprouting from feces. He thought,

pli-tv-kd6:16.2.3.eng: They sprout even after being digested,”

pli-tv-kd6:16.2.4.eng: and being afraid of wrongdoing, he and his followers did not eat mung beans.

pli-tv-kd6:16.2.5.pli: Yepissa sotabbaṃ maññanti, tepi muggaṃ na paribhuñjanti.

pli-tv-kd6:16.2.7.pli: “Sace, bhikkhave, pakkāpi muggā jāyanti, anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yathāsukhaṃ muggaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:16.2.7.eng: “Although mung beans may sprout after being digested, I allow you to eat as much of it as you like.”

pli-tv-kd6:16.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno udaravātābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:16.3.1.eng: On one occasion a certain monk who had a stomachache

pli-tv-kd6:16.3.5.eng: “I allow salty purgatives when you’re sick.

pli-tv-kd6:16.3.6.eng: If you’re not sick, I allow you to drink it mixed with water.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.0.eng: 5. Discussion of the prohibition against storing indoors, etc.

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ tadavasari. Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.1.eng: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Rājagaha where he stayed in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato udaravātābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.2.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had a stomachache.

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando—“pubbepi bhagavato udaravātābādho tekaṭulayāguyā phāsu hotī”ti—
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.3.eng: Venerable Ānanda thought, “Previously, when the Buddha had a stomachache, he was comfortable after drinking the threefold pungent congee.”
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.3.comm: Tekaṭulayāgu is commonly rendered as “rice porridge having three pungent ingredients”. The three are sesame seeds, rice, and mung beans, yet rice and mung beans can hardly be called pungent. I would suggest it is the taste of the combination of the three that is pungent.

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.4.pli: sāmaṃ tilampi, taṇḍulampi, muggampi viññāpetvā, anto vāsetvā, anto sāmaṃ pacitvā bhagavato upanāmesi—
pli-tv-kd6:17.1.4.eng: He then asked for sesame seeds, rice, and mung beans, stored them indoors, cooked them himself indoors, and brought them to the Buddha, saying,

pli-tv-kd6:17.1.5.eng: “Sir, please drink the threefold pungent congee.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.1.pli: Jānantāpi tathāgatā pucchanti, jānantāpi na pucchanti;
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.1.eng: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not.

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.2.pli: kālaṃ viditvā pucchanti, kālaṃ viditvā na pucchanti;
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.2.eng: They know the right time to ask and when not to ask.

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.3.eng: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, otherwise not,

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.4.eng: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.4.comm: “Incapable of doing” renders setughāta, literally, “destroyed the bridge”. Sp 1.16: Setu vuccati maggo, maggeneva tādisassa vacanassa ghāto, samucchedoti vuttaṁ hoti, “The path is called the bridge. What is said is that there is the destruction and cutting off of such speech by the path.” The commentary seems to take setu, “bridge”, as a reference to the eightfold path. I prefer to understand “bridge” as a metaphor for access, that is, the Buddhas no longer have the possibility of doing what is unbeneficial.

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.5.pli: Dvīhi ākārehi buddhā bhagavanto bhikkhū paṭipucchanti— “dhammaṃ vā desessāma, sāvakānaṃ vā sikkhāpadaṃ paññapessāmā”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.5.eng: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi—“kutāyaṃ, ānanda, yāgū”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:17.2.6.eng: So he said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, where does this congee come from?”

pli-tv-kd6:17.2.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesi.

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.2.pli: “ananucchavikaṃ, ānanda, ananulomikaṃ, appatirūpaṃ, assāmaṇakaṃ, akappiyaṃ, akaraṇīyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.2.eng: “It’s not suitable, Ānanda, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.3.pli: Kathañhi nāma tvaṃ, ānanda, evarūpāya bāhullāya cetessasi.
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.3.eng: How could you be so indulgent?

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.4.pli: Yadapi, ānanda, anto vuṭṭhaṃ tadapi akappiyaṃ;
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.4.eng: What’s been stored indoors in a monastery is unallowable;
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.4.comm: Sp 3.274: Antovutthanti akappiyakuṭiyaṁ vutthaṁ, “Antovuttha: stored, apart from the food-storage hut.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.5.eng: what’s been cooked indoors in a monastery is unallowable;
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.5.comm: Khuddasikkhā-abhinavaṭīkā 112: Antopakketi akappiyakuṭiyā anto pakke, “Antopakka: cooked indoors, apart from the food-storage hut.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.6.eng: what’s been cooked by oneself is unallowable.

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.8.pli: vigarahitvā dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.8.eng: After rebuking him, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.9.pli: “na, bhikkhave, anto vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkaṃ paribhuñjitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.3.9.eng: “You shouldn’t eat what’s been stored indoors in a monastery, what’s been cooked indoors in a monastery, or what you have cooked yourself.

pli-tv-kd6:17.3.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.4.1.pli: Anto ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkaṃ tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti tiṇṇaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.4.1.eng: If you eat what’s been stored indoors in a monastery, cooked indoors in a monastery, and cooked by yourselves, you commit three offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.4.2.pli: Anto ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, aññehi pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dvinnaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.4.2.eng: If you eat what’s been stored indoors in a monastery, cooked indoors in a monastery, but cooked by others, you commit two offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.4.3.pli: Anto ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, bahi pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dvinnaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.4.3.eng: If you eat what’s been stored indoors in a monastery, but cooked outside, yet cooked by yourselves, you commit two offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.5.1.pli: Bahi ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dvinnaṃ dukkaṭānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.5.1.eng: If you eat what’s been stored outside, but cooked indoors in a monastery, and cooked by yourselves, you commit two offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.5.2.pli: Anto ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, bahi pakkaṃ, aññehi pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-kd6:17.5.2.eng: If you eat what’s been stored indoors in a monastery, but cooked outside, and cooked by others, you commit one offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.5.3.pli: Bahi ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, aññehi pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-kd6:17.5.3.eng: If you eat what’s been stored outside, but cooked indoors in a monastery, yet cooked by others, you commit one offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.5.4.pli: Bahi ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, bahi pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-kd6:17.5.4.eng: If you eat what’s been stored outside, and cooked outside, but cooked by yourselves, you commit one offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd6:17.5.5.pli: Bahi ce, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhaṃ, bahi pakkaṃ, aññehi pakkaṃ, tañce paribhuñjeyya, anāpattī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.5.5.eng: If you eat what’s been stored outside, and cooked outside, and cooked by others, there is no offense.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.6.2.eng: that the Buddha had prohibited cooking,

pli-tv-kd6:17.6.3.eng: being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not reheat.

pli-tv-kd6:17.6.5.eng: “I allow you to reheat what’s already been cooked.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahaṃ dubbhikkhaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.7.1.eng: At that time Rājagaha was short of food.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.2.pli: Manussā loṇampi, telampi, taṇḍulampi, khādanīyampi ārāmaṃ āharanti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.7.2.eng: People brought salt, oil, rice, and fresh food to the monastery.
pli-tv-kd6:17.7.2.comm: “Fresh food” renders khādanīya. See Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.4.eng: but it was eaten by vermin and stolen by thieves.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.6.eng: “I allow you to store food indoors.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.7.eng: The monks stored it indoors, but it was cooked outside.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.9.eng: and the monks ate in fear.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.12.pli: Dubbhikkhe kappiyakārakā bahutaraṃ haranti, appataraṃ bhikkhūnaṃ denti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.7.12.eng: Because of the famine, the attendants took more for themselves and gave less to the monks.

pli-tv-kd6:17.7.15.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, anto vuṭṭhaṃ, anto pakkaṃ, sāmaṃ pakkan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:17.7.15.eng: I allow you to store food indoors in a monastery, to cook indoors in a monastery, and to cook yourselves.”

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.0.eng: 6. Receiving what has been picked up

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū kāsīsu vassaṃvuṭṭhā rājagahaṃ gacchantā bhagavantaṃ dassanāya antarāmagge na labhiṃsu lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ;
pli-tv-kd6:17.8.1.eng: On one occasion a number of monks who had completed the rainy-season residence in Kāsi were traveling to Rājagaha to visit the Buddha. While on their way, they did not receive sufficient food, whether fine or coarse.

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.3.eng: but no attendant to offer it.

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.4.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū kilantarūpā yena rājagahaṃ veḷuvanaṃ kalandakanivāpo, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd6:17.8.4.eng: When the monks arrived at Rājagaha, they were exhausted. They went to the Bamboo Grove, approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.5.pli: Āciṇṇaṃ kho panetaṃ buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ āgantukehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisammodituṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.8.5.eng: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly-arrived monks,

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā te bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.7.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re getting by?

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.8.eng: I hope you’re not tired from traveling?

pli-tv-kd6:17.8.9.eng: And where have you come from?”

pli-tv-kd6:17.9.1.eng: “We’re keeping well, sir, we’re getting by,”

pli-tv-kd6:17.9.2.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, kāsīsu vassaṃvuṭṭhā rājagahaṃ āgacchantā bhagavantaṃ dassanāya antarāmagge na labhimhā lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ;
pli-tv-kd6:17.9.2.eng: and they told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd6:17.9.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:17.9.6.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:17.9.7.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yattha phalakhādanīyaṃ passati, kappiyakārako ca na hoti, sāmaṃ gahetvā, haritvā, kappiyakārake passitvā, bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipitvā, paṭiggahāpetvā paribhuñjituṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:17.9.7.eng: “If there is no attendant, but you see fruit, I allow you to pick it up yourself. You should then carry it until you see an attendant, put it on the ground, and have it received. You may then eat it.

pli-tv-kd6:17.9.8.eng: I allow you to receive what you have picked up.”

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa navā ca tilā navañca madhu uppannā honti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.1.1.eng: On one occasion a certain brahmin had obtained fresh sesame seed and fresh honey.

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.3.pli: “yannūnāhaṃ nave ca tile navañca madhuṃ buddhappamukhassa bhikkhusaṅghassa dadeyyan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.1.3.eng: “Why don’t I give this to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha?”

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.4.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ paṭisammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
pli-tv-kd6:18.1.4.eng: He then went to the Buddha, exchanged pleasantries with him,

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.6.pli: “adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ, saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.1.6.eng: “Please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.7.eng: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.

pli-tv-kd6:18.1.8.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:18.1.8.eng: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, the brahmin left.

pli-tv-kd6:18.2.1.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi—
pli-tv-kd6:18.2.1.eng: The following morning that brahmin had various kinds of fine foods prepared. He then had the Buddha informed

pli-tv-kd6:18.2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi, saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
pli-tv-kd6:18.2.3.eng: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that brahmin’s house where he sat down on the prepared seat.

pli-tv-kd6:18.2.4.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd6:18.2.4.eng: That brahmin personally served various kinds of fine foods to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, the brahmin sat down to one side.

pli-tv-kd6:18.2.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā, samādapetvā, samuttejetvā, sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:18.2.5.eng: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up and left.

pli-tv-kd6:18.3.1.pli: Atha kho tassa brāhmaṇassa acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd6:18.3.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha had left, that brahmin thought,

pli-tv-kd6:18.3.2.pli: “yesaṃ kho mayā atthāya buddhappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho nimantito, ‘nave ca tile navañca madhuṃ dassāmī’ti, te mayā pamuṭṭhā dātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:18.3.2.eng: “I invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha to give them the fresh sesame seed and honey, but I forgot.

pli-tv-kd6:18.3.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ nave ca tile navañca madhuṃ kolambehi ca ghaṭehi ca ārāmaṃ harāpeyyan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.3.3.eng: Why don’t I take the sesame seed and honey to the monastery in basins and waterpots?”

pli-tv-kd6:18.3.4.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo nave ca tile navañca madhuṃ kolambehi ca ghaṭehi ca ārāmaṃ harāpetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
pli-tv-kd6:18.3.4.eng: And he did just that. He then went up to the Buddha

pli-tv-kd6:18.3.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.1.pli: “yesaṃ kho mayā, bho gotama, atthāya buddhappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho nimantito, ‘nave ca tile navañca madhuṃ dassāmī’ti, te mayā pamuṭṭhā dātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.1.eng: “When I invited you for a meal, I forgot to give you these fresh sesame seeds and this honey.

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.2.pli: Paṭiggaṇhātu me bhavaṃ gotamo nave ca tile navañca madhun”ti.

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.3.eng: “Well then, brahmin, give it to the monks.”

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dubbhikkhe appamattakepi pavārenti, paṭisaṅkhāpi paṭikkhipanti,
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.4.eng: At this time, food was scarce, and the monks were refusing invitations to eat more even after taking just a little. After reflection, they were even declining altogether.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.4.comm: “The monks refused an invitation to eat more even after taking just a little” renders appamattakepi pavārenti. The phrase is explained in the sub-commentary at Sp-ṭ 3.276: Appamattakepi pavārentīti appamattakepi gahite pavārenti, “bahumhi gahite aññesaṁ nappahotī”ti maññamānā, “Appamattakepi pavārenti: even when they have taken just a little, they refuse an invitation to eat more, thinking, ‘If much is taken, there will not be enough for others.’”

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.5.pli: sabbo ca saṅgho pavārito hoti. Bhikkhū kukkuccāyantā na paṭiggaṇhanti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.5.eng: And so now that the whole Sangha was being invited, being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.5.comm: Apart from their restraint due to the scarcity of food, they did not want to fall into an offense under Bu Pc 35:2.15.1.

pli-tv-kd6:18.4.7.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, tato nīhaṭaṃ bhuttāvinā pavāritena anatirittaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.7.eng: I allow one who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more to eat non-leftovers that have been brought out.”
pli-tv-kd6:18.4.7.comm: Sp 3.276: Tato nīhaṭanti yattha nimantitā bhuñjanti, tato nīhaṭaṁ, “Tato nīhaṭan: brought out from where they ate their invitational meal.”

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.0.eng: 7. The allowance for what has been received, etc.

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa upaṭṭhākakulaṃ saṅghassatthāya khādanīyaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.1.eng: On one occasion a family who was supporting Venerable Upananda the Sakyan sent fresh food to the Sangha, saying,

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.2.eng: “After showing it to Venerable Upananda, it’s to be given to the Sangha.”

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā upanando sakyaputto gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.3.eng: Just then Upananda had gone to the village for alms.

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.4.pli: Atha kho te manussā ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhū pucchiṃsu—
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.4.eng: When those people arrived at the monastery, they asked for Upananda

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.6.pli: “Esāvuso, āyasmā upanando sakyaputto gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭho”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.6.eng: and were told where he was.

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.7.pli: “Idaṃ, bhante, khādanīyaṃ ayyassa upanandassa dassetvā saṅghassa dātabban”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.7.eng: They said, “Venerables, after showing it to Venerable Upananda, this fresh food is to be given to the Sangha.”

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.8.eng: The monks told the Buddha. He said,

pli-tv-kd6:19.1.9.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, paṭiggahetvā nikkhipatha yāva upanando āgacchatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.1.9.eng: “Well then, receive it and put it aside until Upananda returns.”

pli-tv-kd6:19.2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto purebhattaṃ kulāni payirupāsitvā divā āgacchati.
pli-tv-kd6:19.2.1.eng: But because Upananda visited families before eating, he returned late to the monastery.

pli-tv-kd6:19.2.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dubbhikkhe appamattakepi pavārenti, paṭisaṅkhāpi paṭikkhipanti, sabbo ca saṅgho pavārito hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.2.2.eng: At this time, food was scarce, and the monks were refusing invitations to eat more even after taking just a little. After reflection, they were even declining altogether. And so now that the whole Sangha was being invited,

pli-tv-kd6:19.2.3.eng: being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.

pli-tv-kd6:19.2.5.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, purebhattaṃ paṭiggahitaṃ bhuttāvinā pavāritena anatirittaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:19.2.5.eng: I allow one who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more to eat non-leftovers that were received before the meal.”

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.3.eng: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato sāriputtassa kāyaḍāhābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.4.eng: At that time Venerable Sāriputta had a fever.

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.5.eng: Venerable Mahāmoggallāna went to him and asked,

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.6.pli: “pubbe te, āvuso sāriputta, kāyaḍāhābādho kena phāsu hotī”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.6.eng: “When you previously had a fever, Sāriputta, how did you get better?”

pli-tv-kd6:20.1.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva jetavane antarahito mandākiniyā pokkharaṇiyā tīre pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.1.8.eng: Then, just as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, Mahāmoggallāna disappeared from the Jeta Grove and reappeared on the banks of the Mandākinī lotus pond.

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.1.pli: Addasā kho aññataro nāgo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ, disvāna āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:20.2.1.eng: An elephant saw Mahāmoggallāna coming and said to him,

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.2.pli: “etu kho, bhante, ayyo mahāmoggallāno. Svāgataṃ, bhante, ayyassa mahāmoggallānassa.

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.5.pli: “Bhisehi ca me, āvuso, attho, muḷālikāhi cā”ti.

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.6.pli: Atha kho so nāgo aññataraṃ nāgaṃ āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.7.pli: “tena hi, bhaṇe, ayyassa bhise ca muḷālikāyo ca yāvadatthaṃ dehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:20.2.7.eng: “Listen, give as many roots and tubers as the venerable needs.”

pli-tv-kd6:20.2.8.pli: Atha kho so nāgo mandākiniṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā, soṇḍāya bhisañca muḷālikañca abbāhitvā, suvikkhālitaṃ vikkhāletvā, bhaṇḍikaṃ bandhitvā yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd6:20.2.8.eng: It plunged into the Mandākinī lotus pond and pulled up lotus roots and tubers with his trunk. It gave them a good rinse, bound them in a bundle, and went up to Mahāmoggallāna.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—mandākiniyā pokkharaṇiyā tīre antarahito jetavane pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.1.eng: Then, just as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, Mahāmoggallāna disappeared from the banks of the Mandākinī lotus pond and reappeared in the Jeta Grove.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.2.pli: Sopi kho nāgo mandākiniyā pokkharaṇiyā tīre antarahito jetavane pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.2.eng: And that elephant did the same.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.3.pli: Atha kho so nāgo āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa bhise ca muḷālikāyo ca paṭiggahāpetvā jetavane antarahito mandākiniyā pokkharaṇiyā tīre pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.3.eng: It had the roots and tubers offered to Mahāmoggallāna, before returning to the Mandākinī lotus pond in the same manner.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmato sāriputtassa bhise ca muḷālikāyo ca upanāmesi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.4.eng: Mahāmoggallāna then brought those lotus roots and tubers to Sāriputta.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmato sāriputtassa bhise ca muḷālikāyo ca bhuttassa kāyaḍāhābādho paṭippassambhi.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.5.eng: When he had eaten them, his fever subsided.

pli-tv-kd6:20.3.6.pli: Bahū bhisā ca muḷālikāyo ca avasiṭṭhā honti.
pli-tv-kd6:20.3.6.eng: But there was much left over.

pli-tv-kd6:20.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dubbhikkhe appamattakepi pavārenti, paṭisaṅkhāpi paṭikkhipanti, sabbo ca saṅgho pavārito hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:20.4.1.eng: At this time, food was scarce, and the monks were refusing invitations to eat more even after taking just a little. After reflection, they were even declining altogether. And so now that the whole Sangha was being invited,

pli-tv-kd6:20.4.2.eng: being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.

pli-tv-kd6:20.4.4.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, vanaṭṭhaṃ pokkharaṭṭhaṃ bhuttāvinā pavāritena anatirittaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:20.4.4.eng: I allow one who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more to eat non-leftovers coming from the forest or a lotus pond.”
pli-tv-kd6:20.4.4.comm: “Non-leftovers” is here used in its technical sense of Bu Pc 35:3.1.9. In other words, the lotus roots and tubers were leftovers that were turned into non-leftovers through the appropriate procedure.

pli-tv-kd6:21.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāvatthiyaṃ bahuṃ phalakhādanīyaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, kappiyakārako ca na hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:21.1.1.eng: On one occasion in Sāvatthī, much fruit had been given, but there was no attendant.

pli-tv-kd6:21.1.2.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not eat it.

pli-tv-kd6:21.1.4.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, abījaṃ nibbattabījaṃ akatakappaṃ phalaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:21.1.4.eng: “I allow you to eat fruit that hasn’t been made allowable if it’s seedless or the seeds have been removed.”
pli-tv-kd6:21.1.4.comm: “The seeds have been removed” renders nibbattabīja. Nibbatta is a past participle that normally means “come into being” or “developed”. According to SED (sv. nir-vṛit), however, it can also mean “removed”. Sp 3.278: Nibbaṭṭabījanti bījaṁ nibbaṭṭetvā apanetvā paribhuñjitabbakaṁ ambapanasādi, “Nibbattabīja means having nibbatta-ed, having removed the seed, mangoes, jackfruit, etc., may be eaten.”

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.0.eng: 8. Discussion of the prohibition against surgery

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:22.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Sāvatthī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-kd6:22.1.3.eng: he stayed in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno bhagandalābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd6:22.1.4.eng: At that time the doctor Ākāsagotta performed surgery on a certain monk who had hemorrhoids.

pli-tv-kd6:22.1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā senāsanacārikaṃ āhiṇḍanto yena tassa bhikkhuno vihāro tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd6:22.1.6.eng: Just then, while walking about the dwellings, the Buddha came to this monk’s dwelling.

pli-tv-kd6:22.2.1.pli: Addasā kho ākāsagotto vejjo bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ, disvāna bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd6:22.2.1.eng: Ākāsagotta saw the Buddha coming and said to him,

pli-tv-kd6:22.2.2.pli: “āgacchatu bhavaṃ gotamo, imassa bhikkhuno vaccamaggaṃ passatu, seyyathāpi godhāmukhan”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:22.2.2.eng: “Good Gotama, please come and see this monk’s anus. It’s just like the mouth of a lizard.”

pli-tv-kd6:22.2.5.pli: tatova paṭinivattitvā, etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā, bhikkhū paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd6:22.2.5.eng: and he turned around right there. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:22.2.6.pli: “atthi kira, bhikkhave, amukasmiṃ vihāre bhikkhu gilāno”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:22.2.6.eng: “Is there a sick monk in such-and-such a dwelling?”

pli-tv-kd6:22.2.9.pli: “Tassa, bhante, āyasmato bhagandalābādho, ākāsagotto vejjo satthakammaṃ karotī”ti.
pli-tv-kd6:22.2.9.eng: “He has hemorrhoids, and the doctor Ākāsagotta is performing surgery.”

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.2.pli: “ananucchavikaṃ, bhikkhave, tassa moghapurisassa, ananulomikaṃ, appatirūpaṃ, assāmaṇakaṃ, akappiyaṃ, akaraṇīyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:22.3.2.eng: “It’s not suitable, monks, for that foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.3.pli: Kathañhi nāma so, bhikkhave, moghapuriso sambādhe satthakammaṃ kārāpessati.
pli-tv-kd6:22.3.3.eng: How can he have surgery on the private parts?

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.4.pli: Sambādhe, bhikkhave, sukhumā chavi, duropayo vaṇo, dupparihāraṃ satthaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:22.3.4.eng: The skin is delicate in that area, sores heel with difficulty, and a scalpel is hard to wield there.

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.7.eng: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.8.eng: “You shouldn’t have surgery on the private parts.
pli-tv-kd6:22.3.8.comm: Vjb 3.279: Sambādheti vaccamagge bhikkhussa bhikkhuniyā ca passāvamaggepi anulomato, “Sambādha means the anus of a monk or a nun, and also the genital area accords with this.”

pli-tv-kd6:22.3.9.eng: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū—
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.1.eng: When they heard that the Buddha had prohibited surgery,

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.3.eng: the monks from the group of six had enemas.
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.3.comm: Sp 3.279: Yena kenaci pana cammena vā vatthena vā vatthipīḷanampi na kātabbaṁ, “One should not do bladder-action, vatthipīḷana, with whatever skin or cloth.” Vmv 3.279: Vatthipīḷananti yathā vatthigatatelādi antosarīre ārohanti, evaṁ hatthena vatthimaddanaṁ, “Vatthipīḷana: in order for oils, etc., in a bladder to go up inside the body, thus one squeezes the bladder with the hand.” The meaning is not entirely clear. My rendering is no more than a suggestion.

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.4.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā, te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.4.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.5.eng: “How can the monks from the group of six have enemas?”

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.6.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.6.eng: They told the Buddha what had happened.

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.7.pli: “Saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, chabbaggiyā bhikkhū vatthikammaṃ kārāpentī”ti?
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.7.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are having enemas?”

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.9.pli: vigarahitvā dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.9.eng: After rebuking them, the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.10.pli: “na, bhikkhave, sambādhassa sāmantā dvaṅgulā satthakammaṃ vā vatthikammaṃ vā kārāpetabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.10.eng: “You shouldn’t get surgery within 3.5 centimeters of the private parts or have enemas.
pli-tv-kd6:22.4.10.comm: That is, two fingerbreadths. For a discussion of the aṅgula, see sugata in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd6:22.4.11.eng: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”

pli-tv-kd6:23.1.0.eng: 9. Discussion of the prohibition against human flesh

pli-tv-kd6:23.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena bārāṇasī tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd6:23.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.

pli-tv-kd6:23.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena bārāṇasī tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd6:23.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
pli-tv-kd6:23.1.3.eng: he stayed in the deer park at Isipatana.
